CEM121.name: Explorations in Chemistry
CEM121.description: Introduction to core ideas in chemistry (structure and properties of matter, energy, and electrical forces) blended with science practices (use of models, argumentation, construction of scientific explanations, mathematical thinking) to understand and explain chemical phenomena.
CEM121.prerequisite: (MTH 103 or concurrently) or (MTH 103A or concurrently) or (MTH 103B or concurrently)
CEM121.exclude: CEM 141 or CEM 151 or CEM 181H or LB 171

CEM141.name: General Chemistry
CEM141.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM141.description: Elements and compounds; reactions; stoichiometry; thermochemistry; atomic structure; chemical bonding; states of matter; solutions; acids and bases; aqueous equilibria.
CEM141.prerequisite: ((MTH 103B or concurrently) or (MTH 103 or concurrently) or (MTH 110 or concurrently) or (MTH 116 or concurrently) or (MTH 124 or concurrently) or (MTH 132 or concurrently) or (MTH 152H or concurrently) or LB 118) or designated score on Mathematics Placement test

CEM142.name: General and Inorganic Chemistry
CEM142.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM142.description: Kinetics; gaseous equilibria; acids and bases; pH; buffers; hydrolysis; titrations; heterogeneous equilibria; thermodynamics; redox and electrochemistry; transition metal chemistry; nuclear chemistry; main group chemistry.
CEM142.prerequisite: CEM 141 or CEM 151 or CEM 181H or LB 171

CEM143.name: Survey of Organic Chemistry
CEM143.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM143.description: Chemistry of carbon compounds. Chemistry of the main organic functional groups with applications to everyday life, industry, and biology.
CEM143.prerequisite: CEM 141 or CEM 151 or CEM 181H or LB 171

CEM151.name: General and Descriptive Chemistry
CEM151.description: Stoichiometry; solutions; reactions and thermochemistry; quantum mechanics and atomic structure; periodic properties; chemical bonding; molecular structure; coordination chemistry; organic molecules and functional groups.
CEM151.prerequisite: ((MTH 116 or concurrently) or (MTH 124 or concurrently) or (MTH 132 or concurrently) or (MTH 152H or concurrently) or (LB 118 or concurrently)) or designated score on Mathematics Placement test

CEM152.name: Principles of Chemistry
CEM152.description: Gases, liquids, and solids; thermodynamics; changes of state; solutions and colligative properties; chemical equilibria; acids, bases, and aqueous equilibria; kinetics; redox reactions and electrochemistry; nuclear chemistry.

CEM161.name: Chemistry Laboratory I
CEM161.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM161.description: Introduction to basic chemistry laboratory techniques, including measurements, chemical reactions and basic spectroscopy.
CEM161.prerequisite: (CEM 141 or concurrently) or (CEM 151 or concurrently) or (CEM 181H or concurrently) or (LB 171 or concurrently)

CEM162.name: Chemistry Laboratory II
CEM162.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM162.description: Continuation of CEM 161 with additional emphasis on kinetics, thermochemistry, titration, and synthesis.

CEM181H.name: Honors Chemistry I
CEM181H.description: Atomic structure and quantum mechanics; chemical bonding and molecular structure; spectroscopy; coordination chemistry; materials or biological macromolecules.
CEM181H.prerequisite: (MTH 124 or concurrently) or (MTH 132 or concurrently) or (MTH 152H or concurrently) or (LB 118 or concurrently)

CEM182H.name: Honors Chemistry II
CEM182H.description: Gases, solids, liquids, solutions, and phase transitions; thermodynamics; spontaneity and the second law of thermodynamics; chemical equilibrium; acid-base equilibria; redox reactions and electrochemistry; kinetics.
CEM182H.prerequisite: (CEM 151 or CEM 181H or LB 171) and ((MTH 126 or concurrently) or (MTH 133 or concurrently) or (MTH 153H or concurrently) or (LB 119 or concurrently))

CEM185H.name: Honors Chemistry Laboratory I
CEM185H.description: Spectroscopic methods used to determine the structure of molecules and materials. Experiments applying principles of physical, organic, inorganic, analytical, biological, and materials chemistry, while introducing analytical (qualitative and quantitative) and synthetic techniques.

CEM251.name: Organic Chemistry I
CEM251.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM251.description: Common classes of organic compounds including their nomenclature, structure, bonding, reactivity, and spectroscopic characterization.
CEM251.prerequisite: CEM 141 or CEM 151 or CEM 181H or LB 171

CEM252.name: Organic Chemistry II
CEM252.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM252.description: Continuation of CEM 251 with emphasis on polyfunctional compounds, particularly those of biological interest.

CEM255.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
CEM255.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM255.description: Preparation and qualitative analysis of organic compounds.
CEM255.prerequisite: (CEM 252 or concurrently) and (CEM 161 or LB 171L or CEM 185H)

CEM262.name: Quantitative Analysis
CEM262.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM262.description: Introduction to analytical chemistry and quantitative methods; aqueous solution equilibria and statistics related to quantitative chemical analysis; titrimetric, gravimetric, and spectrophotometric measurements.
CEM262.prerequisite: (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172) and (CEM 162 or CEM 185H or LB 172L)

CEM311.name: Inorganic Chemistry
CEM311.description: Basic symmetry, molecular orbital theory, and valence bond theory applications to inorganic systems. Physical properties and reactivity of transition metal systems.
CEM311.prerequisite: CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172

CEM333.name: Instrumental Methods and Applications
CEM333.description: Principles and applications of instrumental analysis of separation techniques.
CEM333.prerequisite: {(CEM 262) or (CEM 162 and BLD 213L and BLD 313)} and ((CEM 143 or CEM 251 or CEM 351) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

CEM351.name: Organic Chemistry I
CEM351.description: Structure, bonding, and reactivity of organic molecules.
CEM351.prerequisite: CEM 152 or CEM 182H or CEM 142 or LB 172

CEM352.name: Organic Chemistry II
CEM352.description: Carboxylate derivatives. Conjugation. Aromaticity. Amino acids. Proteins. Carbohydrates. Nucleic acids.

CEM355.name: Organic Laboratory I
CEM355.description: Organic laboratory techniques. Distillation. Spectroscopy. Melting points. Recrystallization. Chromatography. Measuring physical properties.
CEM355.prerequisite: (CEM 162 or CEM 185H or LB 172L) and (((CEM 352 or concurrently) or (CEM 252 or concurrently)) and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

CEM356.name: Organic Laboratory II
CEM356.description: Multi-step organic synthesis. Qualitative organic analysis. Separation, identification, and characterization of unknowns.

CEM383.name: Introductory Physical Chemistry I
CEM383.prerequisite: (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172) and (MTH 133 or MTH 153H or MTH 126 or LB 119)

CEM384.name: Introductory Physical Chemistry II
CEM384.prerequisite: (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172) and (MTH 133 or MTH 153H or MTH 126 or LB 119) and (PHY 184 or PHY 232 or PHY 232C or PHY 294H or LB 274)

CEM395.name: Analytical/Physical Laboratory
CEM395.description: Chemical kinetics, thermodynamics, and computer-based data analysis methods.
CEM395.prerequisite: (CEM 483 and (CEM 484 or concurrently) and CEM 262) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

CEM400H.name: Honors Work
CEM400H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM400H.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.

CEM411.name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
CEM411.description: Principles of structure and bonding. Symmetry. Solid state chemistry. Acid-base and redox reactions. Main group chemistry

CEM415.name: Advanced Synthesis Laboratory
CEM415.description: Methods of synthesizing inorganic and organometallic compounds.
CEM415.prerequisite: (CEM 411 and CEM 356) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
CEM415.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Bachelor of Science in Chemistry or in the Lyman Briggs Chemistry Coordinate Major or approval of department.

CEM417.name: Instrumental Methods of Analysis in Neuroscience
CEM417.description: Design, operational principles and practical application of modern instrumental methods used for the separation, identification and quantification of neurochemical species in neuroscience. Application of methods of chemical analysis to study neurosignaling, chemical composition in single secretory cells, chemical structure of cells and tissues.
CEM417.prerequisite: {{(CEM 251 and CEM 252) or (CEM 351 and CEM 352)} and (PHY 231 and PHY 232)} or (PHY 183 and PHY 184) or (PHY 193H and PHY 294H) or (LB 273 and LB 274)

CEM419.name: Independent Study
CEM419.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM419.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

CEM420.name: Independent Research
CEM420.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM420.description: Faculty supervised independent investigations in chemistry.

CEM425.name: Chemistry Communication and Professional Development (W)
CEM425.description: Written and oral communication skills for entering and participating in the chemistry profession and post-undergraduate programs. Includes discussion of academic honesty and research integrity.
CEM425.prerequisite: ((CEM 262) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (CEM 255 or CEM 355)
CEM425.restrictions: Open to students in the Chemistry Major or approval of department.

CEM434.name: Advanced Analytical Chemistry
CEM434.description: Instrumental methods of analysis, including spectroscopy, chromatography, and electrochemistry.

CEM435.name: Analytical Chemistry Laboratory
CEM435.description: Application of instrumental spectroscopic, electrochemical, and chromatographic methods to solve quantitative chemical problems in the laboratory.
CEM435.prerequisite: (CEM 434) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

CEM444.name: Chemical Safety
CEM444.description: Prudent laboratory practices. Regulatory agencies' expectations of chemical industries and academia.
CEM444.prerequisite: (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172) and (CEM 252 or CEM 352)

CEM482.name: Science and Technology of Wine Production
CEM482.description: Origin and history of wine and wine production. Determination and timing of harvest, methods of postharvest handling, storage, and processing of grapes into juice and wine. Physical and chemical changes in wine and processes. Analysis of must and its adjustment, fermentation, fining, and aging. Physiology of yeasts and bacteria involved in winemaking and spoilage. Cellar practices, problems, and operations.
CEM482.restrictions: Open to seniors or graduate students in the Department of Biosystems and Agricultural Engineering or in the Department of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science or in the Department of Chemistry or in the Department of Food Science and Human Nutrition or in the Department of Horticulture or in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics or in the Lyman Briggs Chemistry Coordinate Major. Approval of department.

CEM483.name: Quantum Chemistry
CEM483.description: Postulates of quantum mechanics and the application to model systems, atoms and molecules. Introduction to molecular spectroscopy.
CEM483.prerequisite: (MTH 235 or MTH 347H or MTH 340) and (PHY 184 or PHY 294H or LB 274 or PHY 184B) and (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 181H or LB 172)

CEM484.name: Molecular Thermodynamics
CEM484.description: Microscopic properties of atoms and molecules revealed by spectroscopic measurements; connection between thermodynamic properties of macroscopic chemical systems and microscopic properties established using statistical thermodynamics.
CEM484.prerequisite: (MTH 235 or MTH 340 or MTH 347H) and (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172)

CEM485.name: Modern Nuclear Chemistry
CEM485.description: Elementary nuclear processes and properties; radioactivity, its measurement and its interaction with matter.
CEM485.prerequisite: (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172) and (PHY 184 or PHY 232 or PHY 294H or LB 274)

CEM495.name: Molecular Spectroscopy
CEM495.description: Experiments in electronic and vibrational spectroscopies.
CEM495.prerequisite: (CEM 483 or concurrently) and (CEM 395 or CEM 499) and (CEM 262 and completion of Tier I writing requirement)

CEM499.name: Chemical Physics Seminar
CEM499.description: Written and oral reports on selected journal articles in chemical physics.
CEM499.prerequisite: ((PHY 215) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (MTH 235 or MTH 340 or MTH 347H)

CEM809.name: Drug Discover and Medicinal Chemistry
CEM809.description: Fundamentals of pharmaceutical drug discovery including basic chemistry, drug-design principles, high throughput screening, computational modeling, and drug metabolic pathways.
CEM809.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Chemistry or in the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology or approval of department.

CEM811.name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry I
CEM811.description: Principles of chemical bonding, electronic structure, and reaction mechanisms of main group and transition metal compounds. Concepts of group theory.
CEM811.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM812.name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry II
CEM812.description: Descriptive chemistry of inorganic compounds. Emphasis on synthesis, structure, and reactivity patterns of coordination, organometallic, and solid state compounds of transition metals and main group elements.
CEM812.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM820.name: Organometallic Chemistry
CEM820.description: Organometallic functional groups. Principles of electronic structure, and bonding in organometallic species will be related to reactivity patterns in common systems. Preparation of complexes with applications to catalytic and stoichiometric organic syntheses.

CEM832.name: Mass Spectrometry
CEM832.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM832.description: Instrumentation of mass spectrometry. Interpreting mass spectra of organic and inorganic molecules. Applications to analysis of large molecules and chromatography.
CEM832.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM834.name: Advanced Analytical Chemistry I
CEM834.description: Basic electronics and data acquisition and anaylsis, electrochemistry, and statistics for chemists.
CEM834.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

CEM835.name: Advanced Analytical Chemistry II
CEM835.description: Separations, molecular spectroscopy and mass spectrometry
CEM835.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science or in the School of Criminal Justice.

CEM836.name: Separation Science
CEM836.description: Physical and chemical principles of separations, column technology, and instrumentation for gas, liquid, and supercritical fluid chromatography.
CEM836.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM837.name: Electroanalytical Chemistry
CEM837.description: Modern electroanalytical chemistry. Theory and applications to chemical and biological problems. Coulometry, voltammetry, ion-selective potentiometry, and other electrochemical techniques.
CEM837.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM845.name: Structure and Spectroscopy of Organic Compounds
CEM845.description: Structural and stereochemical principles in organic chemistry. Applications of spectroscopic methods, especially nuclear magnetic resonance, static and dynamic aspects of stereochemistry. Spectroscopy in structure determination.
CEM845.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM850.name: Intermediate Organic Chemistry
CEM850.description: Traditional and modern basic reaction mechanisms and principles and their synthetic applications.

CEM851.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
CEM851.description: Structure, reactivity, and methods. Acid-base reactions, substitution, addition, elimination, and pericyclic processes. Major organic intermediates related to simple bonding theory, kinetics, and thermodynamics.
CEM851.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM852.name: Methods of Organic Synthesis
CEM852.description: Principal reactions leading to carbon-carbon bond formation and functional group transformations. Strategies and methods of organic synthesis.
CEM852.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM881.name: Atomic and Molecular Structure
CEM881.description: Postulates of quantum mechanics, analytical solutions of the Schroedinger equation, theoretical descriptions of chemical bonding, spectroscopy, statistical mechanics, and statistical thermodynamics.
CEM881.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM882.name: Kinetics and Spectroscopic Methods
CEM882.description: Rate equations and mechanisms of chemical reactions
CEM882.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM883.name: Computational Quantum Chemistry
CEM883.description: Computational methods in determining electronic energy levels, equilibrium nuclear configurations, and other molecular properties.

CEM890.name: Chemical Problems and Reports
CEM890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM890.description: Investigation and report of a nonthesis problem in chemistry.

CEM899.name: Master's Thesis Research
CEM899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM899.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Chemistry.

CEM913.name: Selected Topics in Inorganic Chemistry
CEM913.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM913.description: Current research topics in inorganic chemistry.
CEM913.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Chemistry or approval of department.

CEM918.name: Inorganic Chemistry Seminar
CEM918.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM918.description: Advances in inorganic chemistry reported by graduate students.
CEM918.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Chemistry.

CEM924.name: Selected Topics in Analytical Chemistry
CEM924.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM924.description: Advanced computer techniques, surface chemistry, analytical chemistry of polymers, or statistics for chemists.
CEM924.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM938.name: Analytical Chemistry Seminar
CEM938.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM938.description: Advances in analytical chemistry reported by graduate students, faculty, and guest lecturers.
CEM938.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

CEM956.name: Selected Topics in Organic Chemistry
CEM956.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM956.description: Heterocyclic and organometallic chemistry, natural products, photochemistry, free radicals, or reaction mechanisms.
CEM956.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM958.name: Organic Chemistry Seminar
CEM958.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM958.description: Advances in organic chemistry reported by graduate students.
CEM958.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

CEM971.name: Emerging Topics in Chemistry
CEM971.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM971.description: Discussion of a research topic of emerging interest in chemistry. Preparation of a proposal for funding of research.
CEM971.restrictions: Open only to doctoral students in the Chemistry or Chemical Physics major.

CEM985.name: Selected Topics in Nuclear Chemistry
CEM985.description: Nuclear instruments, detectors and electronics, vacuum technology, electric and magnetic properties of nuclei, nuclear simulation tools, or nuclear spectroscopy and reactions.
CEM985.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science or in the Department of Chemistry.

CEM987.name: Selected Topics in Physical Chemistry I
CEM987.description: Topics such as kinetics and photochemistry, macromolecular and surface chemistry, molecular spectroscopy, electric and magnetic properties of matter, or applications of statistical mechanics to chemical problems.
CEM987.restrictions: Open only to doctoral students or approval of department.

CEM988.name: Selected Topics in Physical Chemistry II
CEM988.description: Topics such as analysis and interpretation of molecular spectra, advanced molecular structure theory, magnetic resonance, X-rays and crystal structure, scientific analysis of vacuum systems, or problems in statistical mechanics.
CEM988.restrictions: Open only to doctoral students or approval of department.

CEM991.name: Quantum Chemistry and Statistical Thermodynamics I
CEM991.description: Principles and applications of quantum chemistry. Partition functions, spectroscopic measurements, and thermodynamic applications.
CEM991.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in College of Natural Science or College of Engineering.

CEM992.name: Quantum Chemistry and Statistical Thermodynamics II
CEM992.description: Analytical and numerical methods for solving quantum chemical problems. Statistical mechanics of solids and liquids.

CEM993.name: Advanced Topics in Quantum Chemistry
CEM993.description: Spectroscopic theory, properties of atoms and molecules in electric and magnetic fields, intermolecular forces. Many-body theory, molecular electronic structure, solid state chemistry, or molecular reaction dynamics.
CEM993.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

CEM994.name: Advanced Topics in Statistical Mechanics
CEM994.description: Nonequilibrium statistical mechanics and thermodynamics. Correlation functions and spectroscopy, light scattering, magnetic relaxation, transport properties of fluids and gases, or statistical mechanics of chemical reactions.
CEM994.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

CEM995.name: Nuclear Chemistry Seminar
CEM995.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM995.description: Advances in nuclear chemistry reported by graduate students, faculty, and guest lecturers.
CEM995.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Chemistry or in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

CEM998.name: Physical Chemistry Seminar
CEM998.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
CEM998.description: Advances in physical chemistry reported by graduate students.
CEM998.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Chemistry.

CEM999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
CEM999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
CEM999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Chemistry.
